item.title: Call for expressions of interest, Juan de la Cierva fellowships
item.description:
The Systems Biology of Host-Microbiome Interactions group is looking to recruit a postdoc in bioinformatics through the national Juan de la Cierva call. Different projects are available in the context of national or european projects.

The postdoc will be hosted at the Centro de Investigación Príncipe Felipe (CIPF) in Valencia, Spain, a leading biomedical institute developing competitive and internationally relevant research in the fields of metabolic disorders, cancer and neuronal pathologies. The research centre, located in Valencia, occupies an area of 32,000m2 and it is equipped with the most advanced infraestructures, facilities and technological equipment.

Responsibilities and qualifications

We are looking for a candidate with a PhD in bioinformatics or related field, deep knowledge of R and or Python, as well as of HPC environments. Experience in metagenomics data processing and analysis is required, and familiarity with containers (Docker, Singularity) and with workflow managers (Nextflow, Snakemake) is a plus.

What we offer:

We offer to host the candidate’s application for the upcoming Juan de la Cierva Call, offering to cover the position of the candidate for up to 1 year until the resolution of the call. Salary level follows CIPF salary scales for postdoctoral researchers (R2 category), in agreement with the corresponding collective agreement (Convenio de la Sanidad Privada de la Provincia de Valencia).

The CIPF promotes equal treatment and opportunities between women and men, which should be considered a fundamental aspect of the CIPF’s labor relations and human resources management. In addition, the CIPF is committed to reconcile a work and family life of its employees and are offering the possibility to benefit from flexible working hours. The CIPF is committed to complying with the European Charter for Researchers and the Code of Conduct for the Recruitment of Researchers (EU Charter & Code) by developing its human resources strategy for researchers (HRS4R) and through its open, transparent, and merit-based recruitment policy (OTM-R)

How to apply:

Interested candidate should send their CV, cover letter and contact details for two references to the following email address: vllorens (at) cipf (dot) es. The CV should remove all personal references to gender, age, marital status, nationality and should not include a photograph. You can apply by clicking.

item.title: Verónica Lloréns presents REGUBIOME at the outreach event "Una horchata por la salud"
item.description:
Verónica Lloréns presented the ERC StG project REGUBIOME to the general public in an outreach event organized by FECYT in the context of the Spanish presidency of the Council of the European Union and the conference on Personalized Medicine that is taking place in Valencia these days.

The organizers of the event “Una horchata por la ciencia” invited local researchers working on EU-funded projects, to bring excellent science being done in Valencia closer to the public.

item.title: Invited talk at CABD
item.description:
Our group leader, Verónica Lloréns-Rico, gave an invited talk at the Centro Andaluz de Biología del Desarrollo (CABD).

She presented her previous work, as well as her vision for her newly established lab. The day was completed with plenty of discussions with the different groups at the CABD. Thanks a lot for the invitation, especially to Prof. Peter Askjaer for hosting!

item.title: Mechanisms of gene regulation
item.description:
Bacteria have a large functional plasticity that allows them to adapt to changing environments and to respond to different stimuli to survive. This functional plasticity is well understood for some model bacteria in vitro, yet the implications in complex ecosystems such as the gut microbiome are unclear. We aim at understanding how is gene expression regulated in gut bacteria, exploring i) what are the stimuli triggering specific gene expression changes, and ii) what are the molecular mechanisms underlying such specific responses, that is, which transcriptional regulators are involved. This will allow us to design targeted strategies for functional modulation of these bacteria in the future.

Related projects:

  • REGUBIOME (ERC StG 2023) - “Transcriptional REGUlation as a mediator of bacterial interactions in the microBIOME”.

item.title: Drivers of transcriptional variation
item.description:
The composition of the gut microbiota is impacted by several factors: host age, sex and BMI; dietary habits; drug intake… However, we know very little of how these factors impact transcriptional variation in the microbiota. We will use cohort studies to address the impact of both extrinsic and intrinsic factors in the functionality of the gut microbiota.

Related projects:

  • MicroTV (Proyectos de Generación de Conocimiento 2022): Characterization of the MICRObial Transcriptional Variation and its sources in the gut ecosystem

item.title: Functional alterations in disease
item.description:
It is well known that the gut microbiota performs key functions to maintain host health, and alterations in those functions are linked to different disorders. We are interested in deciphering the functional changes occurring in different metabolic disorders. We will study expression changes both globally, considering the entire ecosystem, and focusing on specific bacteria of interest. Our goal is to find potential biomarkers for early diagnosis and patient stratification, allowing for improved treatment strategies.
